DataElement.preferredName: MRI Magnetic Field Strength Tesla Float
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The MRI magnet field strength measured in tesla (T).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: MRI Unit of Magnetic Field Strength
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Nominal field strength of the MR Magnet, in Tesla.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Property.preferredName: Magnet Unit of Magnetic Field Strength
Property.preferredDefinition: A device that attracts iron and produces a magnetic field.:A unit of magnetic field strength.

Concepts.definition: A device that attracts iron and produces a magnetic field.
A unit of magnetic field strength.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

DataElementConcept.origin: ACRIN:American College of Radiology Imaging Network
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: TL released 2/23/22. 11/21/12 jc update concepts for ACRIN 6701 study.  5/14/08 - created to support DICOM and ACRIN DCE-MRI data element.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The unit of magnetic flux density in the SI, equal to the magnitude of the magnetic field vector necessary to produce a force of one newton on a charge of one coulomb moving perpendicular to the direction of the magnetic field vector with a velocity of one meter per second. It is equivalent to one weber per square meter._A number that can have its decimal point in any position.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

It is equivalent to one weber per square meter.:A number that can have its decimal point in any position.

Concepts.definition: A SI unit of magnetic flux density equal to the magnitude of the magnetic field vector necessary to produce a force of one newton on a charge of one coulomb moving perpendicular to the direction of the magnetic field vector with a velocity of one meter per second. It is equivalent to one weber per square meter.
A number that can have its decimal point in any position.
